Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Socially Relevant Computing and Analytics

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This "Socially Relevant Computing and Analytics" Research Experiences for Undergraduates Site (SRCA-REU) will immerse a diverse group of undergraduates in a vibrant research community of faculty and graduate students working on cutting-edge interactive and intelligent media, improving learning and healthcare outcomes, educational technologies, and diverse forms of interaction with and through computers. Students will be recruited from underrepresented groups and colleges and universities with limited research opportunities through the STARS Computing Corps, an NSF-funded national consortium of institutions dedicated to broadening participation in computing. The project's focus on relevant cutting edge technologies is a proven focus that can improve retention for minorities and women.

The intellectual merit of the SRCA-REU project lies in the discovery and evaluation of innovative, interactive solutions to open problems in serious games, data analytics, automated camera control, narrative generation, and animal-computer interaction. The SRCA-REU will provide explicit research mentoring training to faculty and graduate student mentors, and explicitly encourage faculty and student publication of results. SRCA-REU students will present their work at an undergraduate research competition, and will be encouraged to submit their technical papers as peer reviewed publications. Using the Affinity Research Groups and STARS Training for REUs models, faculty and graduate student mentors will be engaged with undergraduates to create a supportive culture of collaboration while promoting individual contributions to research through just-in-time training for both mentors and students throughout the summer.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

POR.DRECONTENT:
From 2017-2019, the Socially Relevant Computing and Analytics (SRCA) REU Site program, led by PI Tiffany Barnes, has hosted 54 research experiences for undergraduates at North Carolina State University. Due to our targeted recruitment and selection processes, our overall Site implementation has attracted more women and underrepresented minorities participants than is nationally recognized in Computer Science (Taulbee Report 2016). Women have represented 44.4% (24/54) of our participants, and underrepresented minority students have represented 16.6% (9/54) of our participants, compared to 17% and 13% respectively nationwide. Our SRCA REU Site has also demonstrated a strong commitment to providing research opportunities for students that may not otherwise have access; 38.8% of our participants are from non-doctoral institutions.

 The SRCA REU immersed a diverse group of undergraduates in a vibrant research community working on cutting-edge research including serious games and game analytics; computer science educational technologies and analytics, and machine learning for education, healthcare, and food banks. The SRCA REU designed and implemented a tiered Mentor Training model to create a supportive culture. The tiered mentoring approach is valued by the REU students and is also effective in providing faculty and graduate student mentors with the opportunity to develop their mentoring and research project management skills. In addition to our faculty and graduate mentoring structure, in 2019, REU participants, in turn, mentored diverse high school interns for two weeks.  Each undergraduate research team was paired with 2 interns each week.  REU participants guided their interns in conducting field study observations, data wrangling, and other tasks relevant for the on-going REU research studies. This experience contributes to the opportunities our REU students have to build their scientific leadership and research skills, which were shown to reflect significant increases from pre- to post-survey. Each year, REU students presented their work at an undergraduate research symposium and were encouraged to submit their technical papers as peer reviewed publications.


Intellectual merit: The SRCA REU program has created an immersive research experience for a diverse group of students in order to prepare and motivate students to pursue graduate studies, and advance their career readiness. We contributed to the computing research knowledge through research projects across six labs dedicated to providing cutting-edge solutions to vexing educational, games, healthcare, and foodbank challenges. We determined the most important factors in building student confidence and readiness for advanced academic and career pursuits is in the mentoring relationships and infrastructures that support and sustain immersive research practices. Our SRCA REU program has developed Mentor Training materials and common practices to provide support for effective and supportive experiences for faculty, graduate mentors, and undergraduate REU participants. Each year, both faculty and graduate student mentors participate in our SRCA Mentor Training workshop with support for learning about logistical facets of mentoring as well as how to be intentional about providing support and check-ins with students. The Mentor Training workshop also addressed stress management and attentiveness to mental well-being. Furthermore, SRCA provided mentors with sample REU project schedules and encouraged groups to follow the Affinity Research Groups model which encourages co-creating research agendas and plans with REU participants. REU participants also report high levels of satisfaction with mentoring and overall program satisfaction year after year.  Based on surveys of REU participants, Mentoring and Program Satisfaction are consistently highly regarded by students, with mean scores from 4.35 to 4.85 each year. Focus groups revealed strong evidence that the program is providing a welcoming environment for students to learn new skills, both technical, academic and personal, reflecting themes of increased interest in graduate school, self-discovery, and students finding a sense of meaning in their summer research projects. These findings show that the students found the program to be supportive of  their skill development,  building their confidence, and a valuable experience with strong mentoring.  The students from the three years of student cohorts have produced 4 conference proceedings and two journal articles. 


Broader impacts: The principal outcome of this project was an increase in the interest in, preparation for, and enrollment in graduate degree programs in computing. We have contributed to the doctoral pipeline in computing not only by preparing undergraduate students for advanced study, but also in training current doctoral students in mentoring excellence to prepare them for academic life. An alumni follow up survey was conducted across the three 2017-2019 cohorts of REU students during March of 2020. REU Alumni reported that the experience contributed substantially to their academic and career development. Themes across the responses indicated skill development, awareness of their potential, and understanding of what research careers can look like, with one representative quote stating: “My REU experience gave me insight into what graduate school in computer science is like. Additionally, I gained valuable experience in software development, teamwork, and research.”
